moves.1. e4 c5: as was to be expected: the Sicilian...
moves.2. f4: I am not the kind of player, that strives for d4 and contest c5: quite the contrary...
moves.3. Nf3 Bg7 4. g3: also d3 was possible: but White wants to keep the LSB diagonal open for now...
moves.4... e6: serving multiple purposes: mostly preparing Ne7 and d5...
moves.5. c3: a prophylactic move, against Nb8-c6-b4/d4: White has to wait, how Black responds...
moves.5... Ne7: Nf6, might have induced e5: I would have played d3...
moves.6. Bg2: Black has prepared castling: White has to keep up...
moves.6... O-O 7. O-O d6: a direct d5 is useless: e5 and d3, are both sound replies...
moves.8. d3: also for White, d4 is of little use: it is too early, for opening up the position...
moves.8... b6: preparing Bb7: supporting an eventual d5...
moves.9. Be3: while this might support an upcoming d4...
moves.9... Bb7 10. Nbd2 Nd7: not unclever: supporting c5 and covering square e5...
moves.11. Qc2: not really a plan involved: we are finishing development...
moves.12. a4: first things first: keep b5 under control for a while; the Sicilian is all about pushing forward Black Queens' wing...
moves.12... Rac8: thematic in most Sicilian play: upon breaking up the center, the Queen has to be covered...
moves.13. Rfc1: same shit, different smell: White is also preparing b4 and d4...
moves.14... Nf6: seemingly an attack on pawn e4, after d5: and e4-e5, is no threat anymore; but the real threat is Ng4; at least, that is what Black thinks...
moves.15. Ra2: the final preparation for b4: covering the White Queen twice; but Black is too occupied...
moves.15... Ng4 16. Bf2: simple, yet very effective: the DSB has run its' course, and can be traded...
moves.16... Nxf2: practically forced: h3 is not far away...
moves.17. Kxf2: the old White man comes into play...
moves.17... Rfd8: not sure, if this is best: Black might have tried e5...
moves.18. b4 c4: maybe best: after cxb4, cxb4, Qxb2, Rxb2, Black has little to hope for...
moves.19. d4: and thus, White has conquered the center...
moves.19... f5: an old fox, never loses his tricks: exf5, Nxf5, would be very pleasant for Black; and e4 is attacked twice...
moves.20. e5: I also looked at Ng5 to cover for e4, with Nxe6 as a prospect: but after Qd7, the Knight gets lost after Bf6 or h6...
moves.22. Rd1: problem solved: this is also supporting d4...
moves.23... Rdf8: this is maybe, why Rf8 should have stayed put: Black wants to prepare f4...
moves.25... Ne3: but there is no way back...
moves.26. Nxe3 fxe3+ 27. Rxe3: Nf3 has to be covered twice: so this is pretty much forced...
moves.28... Qf7 29. Qf2 Bxf3: suddenly, Ng5 is a nasty threat: the White Queen is covered twice...
moves.32... Qxe3+: Black might have tried Qb1: but after Rd2, Qxa4, Bb7, Black is faced with all kinds of problems...
moves.33. Kxe3: White has reached a position with roughly one pawn behind: but way more space and play; both Black Rooks are useless for now...
moves.33... Rc7: a logical move: prevent Bb7, and prepare doubling Rooks...
moves.34. h4: White takes up as much space as possible, before the shit hits the fan...
moves.34... Rcf7 35. Rf2: so far, Black has no real grip on the White position: there are no straight winning chances for both; so he decides to equalize...
moves.35... Rf7xf3+ 36. Rxf3 Rxf3+ 37. Kxf3: only to realize, he equalized into a lost position...
moves.37... Kf7 38. Ke4: d5 is inevitable and winning: so Black resigned...

gameName: OTB training game: for old times sake...
